On your own expense

title: Louisa & Jacob
Where to stay?
text:
Where to stay?
The venue offers a limited numbers of rooms that are available for rent with a 10 percent discount. You can find the link for booking with a discount here.
However, there are plenty of places to stay in Copenhagen. If you want to stay near the venue, you can check Fairfield by Marriott Copenhagen Nordhavn or Audo House. Yet, it is easy to get to and from the venue with a short metro ride. Thus, if you want to stay elsewhere this is perfectly doable. If you want something affordable but decent, Jacob can recommend Wakeup Borgergade.


What to do?
Copenhagen is - and this is the Economist who says it, not Jacob - the best city in the world, at least to live in. There are a lot of places to eat and drink and more than enough to see for a weekend. You can probably find a gazillion guides for Copenhagen. However, we wanted to give you some recommendations for our favorite places to go:

To visit
There is more to Copenhagen than Tivoli and Nyhavn. Here are some of our favorites:

If you are into art, we can recommend visiting SMK, Den Hirschsprungske Samling and Davids Samling. If you want to go a bit further, Louisiana is always worth a visit.
There are many nice parks to hang out in Copenhagen. If you want a bit of green in the city, you can go and visit Kongens Have, Søndermarken/Frederiksberg Have, Botanisk Have or Kastellet.
If you want to explore Denmark’s more or less interesting history, you can stop by Nationalmuseet, Folketinget (free access to the tower) or Rosenborg Slot.



To eat
Noma, the Alchemist, and Geranium. Copenhagen is famous for its gastronomic scene. However, there are many other places to visit that are far more affordable. We can recommend booking through earlybird.dk if you want to save a bit of money, although you can only book on the day. Here are some of our favorites:

Torvehallerne is a foodmarket where you can find whatever your heart desires. Louisa spent a significant share of her stipend there when living in Copenhagen and she recommends Smag for a good salad and Coffee Collective for a coffee. It is also a good place to go if you want to try Danish specialties like open faced rye bread sandwiches (yes, it is a specialty).
Aamans is a good choice if you want to try Danish food. They have a handful of branches, ranging from more affordable (Aamans Genbo and Aamans Deli) to more expensive (Aamans 1921).
Baka d’Busk, Bistro Lupa and VeVe have one thing in common: they are all vegetarian. And since Louisa is vegetarian we encourage you to explore Copenhagen’s vegetarian food scene.
Copenhagen has a surprisingly good food scene for Vietnamese food and Asian food more generally. Here are some good choices: Pho Hanoi, Phonk and Cholon.
Copenhagen has been ravaged by the terrible burger and pizza wars. Some of the good places for pizza are Diamond Slice, Pizza Lucca and Mamemi, while Fatty’s, Dandelion and POPL serve a tasty burger.



To eat (baked stuff & brunch)
Copenhagen is famous for its bakeries, and no visit is complete without going to at least three bakeries. Here are four places that won’t leave you dissapointed:

Juno is the bakery to rule them all, at least if you ask Louisa, who goes for a daily pilgrimage there when she visits Copenhagen. Try out their almond croissant or cardamom buns.
Andersen & Maillard is a good place to start. The pistachio croissant is delicious, but you can also try their BMO. That is a unncessary Danish acronoym for Bolle med ost (Bun with cheese).
Democratic Coffee is arguably not the top bakery in Copenhagen. But we lived next to one on our exchange to Copenhagen, and spend a non-negligible amount of money there. They have good coffee and decent baked goods.
Kismet is right across from where we used to go to the gym. And to contravene our gains, we often went there for baked goods or a brunch. It is great and affordable.
Seks is right in the center and Louisa claims she had the best BMO ever there.



To drink
You can drink other beverages than Carlsberg in Copenhagen. Here are some places to go for drinks or beer:

Copenhagen has many great places to go for beers. Søernes Ølbar, Godt Øl and BRUS are a few options, but there are so many more.
When it comes to wine Louisa did a good deal of research when studying in Copenhagen. She recommends Melo, Husted Vin and Nebbiolo.

title: Louisa and Jacob’s wedding
text:
Saturday 5th of September, 2026



Our wedding is on the 5th of September, 2026 in Copenhagen. On the day of the wedding there will be a ceremony, reception, dinner and a party. However, we also plan to schedule some events and sightseeing the day before and the day after the wedding, which we very much hope you would like to attend. The dinner and party will be at Nordhus, but see the program for more information. We would love to see you on our special day, and you can reply using the RSVP! Please let us know before March 15th.
We will keep this website updated with details and upload the photos afterwards.

title: Practical details
text:
Practical details
The ceremony
If we are lucky enough to get a spot, the ceremony will be held at the Copenhagen City Hall. We will update with information when we know more.
Getting to the venue
The venue, Nordhus, is located in the Nordhavn area of Copenhagen. It is accessible by both metro (Nordhavn Metro Station) and trains (Nordhavn Station). However, we will also organize transport for everyone from the ceremony to the venue, so you don’t really need to worry about this unless you get there on your own.
Kids
The party itself is without kids. However, kids are welcome at the reception and before the dinner (until 18ish).
Dresscode
Danes and Norwegians are usually fairly formal when it comes to weddings, meaning a suit for men and a dress for women. However, we want people to feel relaxed and come in what they feel comfortable wearing.
Speeches and other fun things
People are welcome to give a speech or come up with other fun ideas. The venue should be able to accommodate music, screenings and slides. However, we would be very happy if people could keep it short, preferably less than 10 minutes. We hope to keep the dinner short, at least compared to a normal Danish wedding, so we can get partying. If you want to give a speech, please contact our toastmaster (name and contact information will come soon).
Gifts
Every gift is cherished, but we do not get disappointed if you do not give a gift. Louisa has some very ambitious travel plans on behalf of us both, so we would be happy for donations. They can be given at Mobile Pay: 51342188, Vipps: 40094261, Revolut: @jnyrup, or Bank transfer: INSERT WEDDING ACCOUNT. Yet, if you prefer to give something more tangible then we are collecting porcelain from Lyngby Porcelæn.
